Performance Data Examples

Source: vignettes/performance_table_examples.Rmd
performance_table_examples.Rmd
library(rtichoke)

It is useful to work with Performance Datas for most functions in {rtichoke}.

There are several different cases for different Performance Datas:

1. One model for one population

When the user just want to observe the performance of one model.

One can use a single vector as an input for the probs argument:


one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
  real = example_dat$outcome)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 14
#>   threshold    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity   FPR  lift specificity   PPV
#>       <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1      0       50     0     0   100           1  1     1           0    0.333
#> 2      0.01    50    51     0    49           1  0.49  1.52        0.51 0.505
#> 3      0.02    50    55     0    45           1  0.45  1.58        0.55 0.526
#> 4      0.03    50    61     0    39           1  0.39  1.69        0.61 0.562
#> 5      0.04    50    67     0    33           1  0.33  1.81        0.67 0.602
#> 6      0.05    50    67     0    33           1  0.33  1.81        0.67 0.602
#> # … with 4 more variables: NPV <dbl>, positives <int>, NB <dbl>,
#> #   predicted_positives_percent <dbl>

one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
  real = example_dat$outcome,
  stratified_by = "predicted_positives")

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_vector_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 14
#>   threshold predicted_positives…    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity   FPR  lift
#>       <dbl>                <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     0.996                 0        0   100    50     0        0        0   NaN
#> 2     0.994                 0.01     1   100    49     0        0.02     0     3
#> 3     0.994                 0.02     1   100    49     0        0.02     0     3
#> 4     0.986                 0.03     5   100    45     0        0.1      0     3
#> 5     0.982                 0.04     5   100    45     0        0.1      0     3
#> 6     0.982                 0.05     5   100    45     0        0.1      0     3
#> # … with 5 more variables: specificity <dbl>, PPV <dbl>, NPV <dbl>,
#> #   positives <int>, NB <dbl>

Or alternatively a list with a single vector. In that case a column named “model” will be added to the Performance Data, it is recommended to name the vectors:


one_pop_one_model_as_a_list <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Logistic Regression" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities),
  real = example_dat$outcome)

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_list)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 15
#>   model    threshold    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity   FPR  lift specificity
#>   <chr>        <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>
#> 1 Logisti…      0       50     0     0   100           1  1     1           0   
#> 2 Logisti…      0.01    50    51     0    49           1  0.49  1.52        0.51
#> 3 Logisti…      0.02    50    55     0    45           1  0.45  1.58        0.55
#> 4 Logisti…      0.03    50    61     0    39           1  0.39  1.69        0.61
#> 5 Logisti…      0.04    50    67     0    33           1  0.33  1.81        0.67
#> 6 Logisti…      0.05    50    67     0    33           1  0.33  1.81        0.67
#> # … with 5 more variables: PPV <dbl>, NPV <dbl>, positives <int>, NB <dbl>,
#> #   predicted_positives_percent <dbl>

one_pop_one_model_as_a_list_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Logistic Regression" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities),
  real = example_dat$outcome,
  stratified_by = "predicted_positives")

head(one_pop_one_model_as_a_list_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 15
#>   model    threshold predicted_positi…    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity   FPR
#>   <chr>        <dbl>             <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 Logisti…     0.996              0        0   100    50     0        0        0
#> 2 Logisti…     0.994              0.01     1   100    49     0        0.02     0
#> 3 Logisti…     0.994              0.02     1   100    49     0        0.02     0
#> 4 Logisti…     0.986              0.03     5   100    45     0        0.1      0
#> 5 Logisti…     0.982              0.04     5   100    45     0        0.1      0
#> 6 Logisti…     0.982              0.05     5   100    45     0        0.1      0
#> # … with 6 more variables: lift <dbl>, specificity <dbl>, PPV <dbl>, NPV <dbl>,
#> #   positives <int>, NB <dbl>

2. Several models for one population

When the user wants to compare several models.

One needs to use a list with a vector for each population as an input for the probs argument. it is recommended to name the vectors:


one_pop_three_models <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Good Model" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
               "Bad Model" = example_dat$bad_model,
               "Random Guess" = example_dat$random_guess),
  real = example_dat$outcome)

one_pop_three_models_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("Good Model" = example_dat$estimated_probabilities,
               "Bad Model" = example_dat$bad_model,
               "Random Guess" = example_dat$random_guess),
  real = example_dat$outcome, 
  stratified_by = "predicted_positives")

3. Several Populations

When the user wants to compare model performance on different populations. Might be usefull when the user wants to check the consistensy of the model among different populations, a test-train split or fairness analysis might be good use cases.

One needs to use a list with a vector for each model as an input for the probs argument and for the real argument. A column named “population” will be added to the Performance Data, it is recommended to name the vectors:


train_and_test_sets <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("train" = example_dat %>%
                 dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities),
               "test" = example_dat %>% dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities)),
  real = list("train" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome),
              "test" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome)))

head(train_and_test_sets)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 15
#>   population threshold    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity   FPR  lift
#>   <chr>          <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 train           0       28     0     0    68           1 1      1   
#> 2 train           0.01    28    36     0    32           1 0.471  1.6 
#> 3 train           0.02    28    39     0    29           1 0.426  1.68
#> 4 train           0.03    28    43     0    25           1 0.368  1.81
#> 5 train           0.04    28    46     0    22           1 0.324  1.92
#> 6 train           0.05    28    46     0    22           1 0.324  1.92
#> # … with 6 more variables: specificity <dbl>, PPV <dbl>, NPV <dbl>,
#> #   positives <int>, NB <dbl>, predicted_positives_percent <dbl>

train_and_test_sets_enforced_percentiles_symmetry <- prepare_performance_data(
  probs = list("train" = example_dat %>%
                 dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities),
               "test" = example_dat %>% dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                 dplyr::pull(estimated_probabilities)),
  real = list("train" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "train") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome),
              "test" = example_dat %>% 
                dplyr::filter(type_of_set == "test") %>%
                dplyr::pull(outcome)), 
  stratified_by = "predicted_positives")

head(train_and_test_sets_enforced_percentiles_symmetry)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 15
#>   population threshold predicted_positives_…    TP    TN    FN    FP sensitivity
#>   <chr>          <dbl>                 <dbl> <int> <int> <int> <int>       <dbl>
#> 1 train          0.996                  0        0    68    28     0      0     
#> 2 train          0.994                  0.01     1    68    27     0      0.0357
#> 3 train          0.994                  0.02     1    68    27     0      0.0357
#> 4 train          0.990                  0.03     3    68    25     0      0.107 
#> 5 train          0.984                  0.04     4    68    24     0      0.143 
#> 6 train          0.974                  0.05     5    68    23     0      0.179 
#> # … with 7 more variables: FPR <dbl>, lift <dbl>, specificity <dbl>, PPV <dbl>,
#> #   NPV <dbl>, positives <int>, NB <dbl>
